content:
✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Approved since the question is cool! :)

"the position of the numbers is flipped" - I understood this as position of digits within a number for example 18 become 81.
Maybe "the position of both numbers in the equation are flipped" would make it more intuitive? But yeah it can be figured out since you've already given an example "18 + 17" to "21 + 81" which shows both numbers flipping.
I think a subtraction or division example may be more insightful than an addition example up front.

It took me 10 mins to solve though, not less than 5 like the approval checklist, mainly because of needing to remove leading zeros.

Just another way to solve: I used string replacement instead of converting chars to ints and back, and eval in python3.

I liked this challenge but it took me over 15 minutes in JavaScript. (I think this is the second time I ran out of time in over 100 Clashes.) I would have been able to do it a fair amount faster in Python. People using other languages like C, Go, or Java might need more than 15 minutes too. Maybe you could make it slightly easier by:
1. Getting rid of the trailing zeroes in #2 and #4 which become leading zeroes when upside down. 0027 != 27 in some languages. (I used `eval` to save keystrokes.)
2. Getting rid of division and maybe even subtraction to reduce keystrokes.
Just my 2c, it's up to you. I like this challenge other than running out of time.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: I accept this contribution for its creative problem-solving challenge and clear examples.

This is a great puzzle, but it will put some languages at an advantage, such as python with all of it's builtins:
print(round(eval(' '.join([x.strip('0')for x in input().translate(str.maketrans('2769','7296'))[::-1].split()]))))

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Works perfect accept test 4 division where the input is reverserd (should be 196/2548 = 0,07 instead it's 2548 / 196 = 13). Nice contribution.

Goal
* Please change "follow" to "follows".

* Please fix the typo: substractions => subtractions.

Input
* Please add "positive" before "integers".

* Please format "+", "-", "*" and "/" as {{constants}}.

* Please change "separated by" to "and", and then add "separated by a space" at the end.

Constraints
* Please rewrite as:
Divisions, where needed, will not result in fractions.

Stub generator
* Please change "calc" to "Calculation" for consistency with Input section.

Thanks.

Thanks for your help!
I was not sure when writing the input because I felt like they can now be understood as "18 17 +" instead of "18 + 17". I will leave as you said for now, because I feel like the example provided helps to understand, but if someone else finds it confusing this way, I might change it back.

Thanks for your approvement!

I believe you might have done a mistake in your verification though:
if the student gets the paper saying "9610 / 8457" as the input states, he will read "2548 / 0196", which gives 13.
I will add a second example with a subtraction to be sure it works. Thanks for approving!
Right and for the addition and other operators it doesnt matter the result is the same. My bad, i thought the test was wrong but it was my code. Thanks for the contribution, I liked coding it.

You're welcome.

I had the same thought when I typed my comment. Alternatively, you may write "…the first operand, the operator and the second operand, all separated by a space. The operands are positive integers, and the operator can be {{+}}, {{-}}, {{*}} or {{/}}."

Goal
* You missed a space after "subtractions".

Thanks again.
